Do. 17,
P. I.
1937
Mr. S. W. Morgan,
Pan American Airways Company,
New York.
Dear Stokeley:
I have your memorandum attached to clipping from the New York
Times under Shanghai date line of November 23rd, the article appearing
of Hallett Abend.
If you have not done so would
suggest that you
read Abend's book "Can China Survive"
worthwhile.
In that book in which Abend
â€¢ Billing-
ham,
it was pointed out that the Communists and many war lords in outlying
provinces would
certainly revolt against the Central Government in the event
of a war with Japan and numerous other
predictions were made none of which
has been true
and all of which were slightly cynical with respect to
Chinese in general.
In other words I
is possibly over critical.
On my recent trip to Nanking I learned from the best authority
that in July Chiang Kai-shek called in all of the important
against the Chinese in its earliest stages and
asked them if they would be
willing to support the National Government in the
conduct of such a war.
The unanimous verdict was in favor of war unless Japanese
agression ceased.
The question was then asked by the Generalissimo of the Southern and other
leaders whether or not they would continue to
support the Central Government
after the loss of Shanghai.
There was no hesitancy whatever on the part of the
group present in accepting this possibility and assuring complete support.
The question was then asked whether they would continue
to support the Central
Government following the loss of Nanking and again the support was unanimous.
If we can accept this statement as reasonably reliable it
seems to me that the
war to date has gone pretty much as
the Chinese anticipated and it seems
me at least that if the Chinese morale does not collapse that their position
is gotting stronger all the time while the Japanese position is becoming more
In other words I felt in the beginning and have seen no reason
since to
change my opinion, that the Japanese strategy would be to take North.
blocade all Chinese ports, seize Shanghai and
then stand thus compelling
the Chinese to carry the war against well defended Japanese
positions at points
chosen by the Japanese as the most favorable to defend.
This would have
created a situation where the cost to the Japanese would have been reduced to
a minimum and the Chinese would have been compelled to attack, a form of war-
fare with which they are not familiar.
As against this
strategy the Japanese
to me have made a great mistake in following the Chinese inland.
is now necessary for the Japanese to maintain a precarious service of supply
over a very
wide area and to maintain a front line which in the Nanking area
alone will be more than 500 miles in length. If the present rumors are true
that the Japs expect to attempt to take Canton it seems to me that this will
bring about a unification such as China has never known ard will in turn fur-
ther weaken the Japanese position.
Commentint now upon Abend's statement to the effect that Chinese
possibly lost view of the fact that the Chinese soldier is accustomed to hard
